titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Erich Maria Remarque Papers MSS.095
titlestmt.author: Nicole Greenhouse. 2003 Accretion processed by Liza Harrell-Edge in 2013.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-05-08 12:11:51 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

change.item: Translated and updated for DACS compliance by Nicole Greenhouse

physdesc.extent: in 113 manuscript boxes, 6 half manuscript boxes, 4 card boxes, 20 oversized flat boxes, 3 box binders, 3 oversized folders, 1 film can, 2 record cartons, 1 LP box, and 2 tall manuscript boxes.

did.abstract: Erich Maria Remarque (1898-1970) was a German-born novelist and screenwriter, best known for All Quiet On the Western Front. The collection contains manuscripts and articles written by Remarque, correspondence, personal documents, photographs, clippings, and memorabilia. The collection also includes some materials created by his wife Paulette Goddard.
did.langmaterial: Collection is mostly in English and German, with some Italian, French, Spanish, Dutch, Polish, and other European languages.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Remarque's papers were transferred by Paulette Goddard to New York University beginning in 1977.

Accretions were transferred between 1993 and 2000 from the offices of Richard Kay, who served as a legal and financial advisor to Paulette Goddard. Many of the documents appear to have previously come from the offices of Harriet Pilpel, Erich Remarque's attorney and friend.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The papers of Erich Maria Remarque document his work as a writer: the collection contains manuscripts of his novels, screenplays, scripts, poetry and articles dating from the 1910s until his death in 1970, as well as correspondence related to the publication and publicity of his work. Additionally, the collection is also made up of personal materials related to Remarque, including correspondence, medical documentation, horoscopes, vital records, photographs, memorabilia, and diaries. There are also extensive clipping files as a part of the collection, both related to articles in newspapers and magazines on Remarque as well on topics that pertained to his interests that he wrote about in his novels, such as World War I and II, automobiles, celebrity culture, and other topics on Europe.

Remarque was also an art collector, the collection also consists of correspondence with art dealers and reproductions of art, as well as lists of what art was in his art collection. There is also a significant amount of material in the collection related to his life in Porto Ronco, Switzerland with his wife Paulette Goddard, who was an actress and socialite.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Novelist Erich Maria Remarque was born on June 22, 1898 in Osnabrück, Germany. He spent his childhood in imperial Osnabrück, and later served in the German army in World War I on the Western Front. Remarque's books were burned and banned in Nazi Germany, and he lived in exile in Switzerland and the United States following the revocation of his German citizenship in 1938. Remarque married, divorced, and remarried Ilse Jutta Zambona. In 1958 he married American actress Paulette Goddard, and they remained married until his death.

Remarque is best known for his novel All Quiet On the Western Front, which was first published in 1929. His other published novels include The Road Back (1931), Three Comrades (1936), Flotsam (1941), Arch of Triumph (1945), The Black Obelisk (1956), Heaven Has No Favorites (1961), and The Night in Lisbon (1962). Many of these works were adapted into films, often shortly after their publication. According to the Erich Maria Remarque-Peace Center, Remarque critically examined German history in his works, upholding "the preservation of human dignity and humanity in times of oppression, terror and war." Remarque died on September 25, 1970 in Locarno, Switzerland.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Fales Manuscript Collection (MSS 001) (contains Goethe manuscripts believed to have belonged to Erich Remarque)

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Erich Maria Remarque Papers Accretion; MSS 095; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright was transferred to New York University by Paulette Goddard, Remarque's widow, in 1986.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series 6B is closed due to privacy concerns. The rest of the collection is open to researchers.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: An item level German language inventory for Series 1-11 is available from the Fales Library. Please contact special.collections@nyu.edu for further assistance.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2023, Nicole Greenhouse translated the original German guide to the collection. The folder and item numbers were maintained and box numbers were assigned to each box. Unprocessed materials found in the repository were arranged, described, and put in archival housing. Oversized materials were rehoused by Lizzy Zarate.

Previous to 2023, no processing information was documented. Series 8A and 9A were arranged by subject sometime in between when the original guide was created and 2023. As much as possible the items listed in the guide were identified in the subject based folders and the item numbers from the original guide are listed on the folders.

physdesc.extent: in 34 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mostly contains handwritten and typed drafts of Remarque's novels, poems, essays, articles, scripts, and other writings. Outlines, notes, and clippings pertaining to the writings are also in the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains personal and govermental documents issued to Remarque and his family. It includes marriage certificates, travel documents (including passports), certificates, ticket stubs, tax documents, driver's licenses, citizenship documents, leases, documents related to the villa in Porto Ronco, and other documents. Other materials in the series reflect Remarque and his family's persecution by the Nazis--his sister, Elfriede Scholtz was put to death by the Nazis in 1943.

It also includes family photographs; photos of his villa in Porto Ronco; publicity photographs of Remarque and his novels; photographs of his wives Paulette Goddard and Ilse Jutta Zambona; photographs of his other romantic partners such as Marlene Dietrich and Natasha Paley Wilson; and other photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Erich Remarque Papers Accretion consists of correspondence, notes and contracts primarily dealing with the financial and legal aspects of Remarque's life and works. It also includes ephemera and some audiovisual recordings documenting adaptations of works by Remarque; a small selection of typed short story mauscripts with handwritten notes; some personal correspondence and photographs of Paulette Goddard; correspondence, photos, financial statements and auction catalogs related to the Remarques collections of art, textiles, jewelry and other decorative arts; as well as a small amount of photographs that appear to show city and country scenes in Germany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series I: Literary properties consists of correspondence, memos, contracts, agreements, drafts, royalty statements and notes related to the financial and legal aspects of novels, plays, short stories, articles and screenplays by Erich Maria Remarque, as well as related adaptations. It is organized into subseries arranged alphabetically by work title. Within each subseries, materials are arranged chronologically, and photocopies are filed based on dates of the originals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series VII: Photographs consists of photographs and glass plate negatives, and is separated into three subseries. Subseries A: Erich Remarque consists of photos that appear to date from the 1920s and 1930s and include images of cars, city scenes, and country roads with many pictures of an unidentified woman. Subseries B: Paulette Goddard consists primarily of film promotional stills, along with some personal shots. Subseries C: Art, furniture, jewelry, rugs consists of photos primarily of items belonging to the Remarques that appear to have been used in appraisals and sales.
